questions.text: An old woman presents with a persistent productive cough and clubbing. On auscultation, wheeze and crackles are present. There is no history of fever. Which of the following is the investigation of choice to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of bronchiectasis. HRCT is the investigation of choice - most specific.

Bronchiectasis is a suppurative lung disease with abnormal and irreversible dilatation of the bronchi. It is an end-stage condition of various diseases (infections, congenital or autoimmune disorders) that result in the destruction of the bronchial wall and its surrounding supporting tissues. 

Ried’s classification divides bronchiectasis into 3 types based on the phenotype of the affected bronchi:

  • Cylindrical or tubular (most common)
  • Saccular or varicose
  • Cystic

Traction bronchiectasis is a type of bronchiectasis seen in conditions causing extensive pulmonary fibrosis (tuberculosis, idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis). The mechanical traction due to fibrosis pulls apart the adjacent bronchi, making them distorted and abnormally dilated. There is no destruction of the bronchial wall.

Clinically, they have a chronic productive cough, clubbing, crackles, and rhonchi.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital with a fever and cough. She has a history of repeated chest infections for several years and coughs up yellow-green purulent sputum with some streaky hemoptysis. What could be the underlying condition based on the CT given below?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the CT showing signet ring sign is suggestive of bronchiectasis which can be due to cystic fibrosis.

A history of repeated chest infections is an indication of cystic fibrosis and a major risk factor for the development of bronchiectasis.

questions.text: Which of the following is an unlikely complication in patients with bronchiectasis?
questions.solution:
Lung cancer is not a known complication of bronchiectasis.

Complications of bronchiectasis include:

  • Massive hemoptysis 
  • Empyema and lung abscess
  • Respiratory failure
  • Pulmonary hypertension and cor pulmonale
  • Secondary amyloidosis (AA type)

Chronic and recurrent infections lead to secondary amyloidosis (AA type) and involve the kidneys.

questions.text: A 58-year-old white man presents with a 6-month history of productive cough, weight loss, fever, and night sweats. HRCT shows a cluster of grapes appearance. A biopsy shows features of a non-tuberculous mycobacterial infection. Cystic fibrosis is ruled out. Which of the following drugs is not to be used in the treatment regimen?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of bronchiectasis secondary to a non-tuberculous mycobacterial (NTM) infection. Mucolytic dornase is recommended routinely in cystic fibrosis (CF)-related bronchiectasis but not in non-CF bronchiectasis.

Macrolides (azithromycin or clarithromycin) combined with rifampicin and ethambutol are used in the treatment of non-CF bronchiectasis.

Treatment of bronchiectasis:

  1. Antibiotic therapy: This is used to treat exacerbations and is given for 10-14 days. Commonly administered antibiotics include:
    • Amoxicillin or clarithromycin: First-line drugs
    • Ciprofloxacin: For Pseudomonas aeruginosa
  2. Airway clearance:
    • Postural drainage: This is done by gravity-assisted positioning of the patient and chest physiotherapy.
    • Mucolytic treatment: only in cystic fibrosis patients 
      • Normal or hypertonic saline (≥3%) nebulization
      • Humidified air inhalation
      • Drugs like N-acetylcysteine or carbocysteine
  3. Others:
    • Inhaled bronchodilators like long-acting β2 agonists and anticholinergics
    • Long-term oxygen therapy: In patients with chronic respiratory failure
    • Pulmonary rehabilitation
    • Adequate hydration
    • Resection of a focal area of suppuration, lung transplantation: In refractory cases

questions.text: A college student presents with complaints of fever, chronic productive cough, steatorrhea. There is a past history of recurrent lung infections and multiple hospitalizations with similar complaints. Which of the following is false about this condition?

choices.text: Abnormality in CFTR gene leads to defective calcium transport
Most common mutation is F508 deletion
Males have infertility in adult life

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cystic fibrosis. Abnormalities in cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator protein (CFTR) gene lead to defective chloride transport and not calcium transport. 

Cystic fibrosis is an autosomal recessive disorder affecting the epithelial cells of various exocrine glands of the body. It is caused by mutations in the gene coding for CFTR protein. The most common CFTR mutation is F508 deletion.

The most prominent clinical features of cystic fibrosis are chronic respiratory diseases (fever, productive cough, recurrent lung infections) and pancreatic insufficiency (steatorrhea).

Male patients with cystic fibrosis usually have infertility due to congenital absence of bilateral vas deferens and defective sperm transport, resulting in azoospermia.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents to the clinic with an acute respiratory tract infection. He has a history of asthma associated with recurrent respiratory tract infections and sinusitis. Genetic testing in childhood had revealed CFTR mutations. Which of the following is likely to be decreased in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cystic fibrosis. In these patients, sperm count is most likely to be decreased.

Male patients with cystic fibrosis usually have infertility due to congenital absence of bilateral vas deferens and defective sperm transport, resulting in obstructive azoospermia.

Option A: Sweat chloride levels are elevated (≥60 mEq/L) due to abnormalities in the CFTR protein leading to defective chloride transport. 

Option B: Serum bicarbonate levels are increased due to excessive loss of salt in the sweat resulting in hypochloremic alkalosis.

Option D: Immunoreactive trypsinogen levels are increased due to exocrine pancreatic insufficiency. Measurement of these levels is a diagnostic screening test in newborns.

questions.text: A young boy is being evaluated for cystic fibrosis. Sweat chloride shows values of 38 and 44 mEq/L (normal<40). What is the next best test to confirm the diagnosis of cystic fibrosis?
questions.solution:
DNA analysis is used to confirm the diagnosis of cystic fibrosis in patients with equivocal (one normal and one abnormal value) or frankly normal sweat chloride values. 

The diagnosis is confirmed if both of the following criteria are met:

  • Presence of 
    • Clinical symptoms affecting at least one organ system (respiratory, gastrointestinal, or genitourinary) or 
    • Positive newborn screening or 
    • A sibling with cystic fibrosis 
  • Evidence of dysfunction of the CFTR gene by 
    • Two positive sweat chloride test results obtained on separate days or
    • Identification of two CFTR mutations by genetic testing or
    • An abnormal measurement of nasal potential difference

Option A: 72-hour fecal fat is not used in the diagnosis of CF.

Option B: Measuring the levels of immunoreactive trypsinogen is a screening test in newborns.

Option D: Trans epithelial nasal potential difference measurement can be used as an adjunct to sweat test, but it has limited availability and is predominantly used as a research tool.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy has been having recurrent hospitalizations for infections, since 2 years of age. After a detailed evaluation, a diagnosis of Kartagener's syndrome was made. Which of the following features is not a component of the triad seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Male infertility is typical in Kartagener syndrome, but not a component of the triad.

Kartagener’s syndrome is primary ciliary dyskinesia characterized by the classical triad of:

  • Situs inversus
  • Chronic sinusitis
  • Bronchiectasis

Primary ciliary dyskinesia (also called immotile cilia syndrome) is an autosomal recessive disorder affecting ciliary motility. It occurs due to ultrastructural defects in the dynein arm of cilia. This causes the retention of secretions due to a failed mucociliary clearance mechanism. Clinically, this manifests as chronic sinusitis and recurrent infections that ultimately lead to bronchiectasis.

As ciliary function is necessary to ensure proper rotation of the developing organs in the chest and abdomen, its absence, will lead to situs inversus or a partial lateralizing abnormality.

Male patients with this condition tend to be infertile, due to asthenospermia (immotile spermatozoa due to impaired sperm flagella function).

questions.text: Infertility in Kartagener’s syndrome is due to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Kartagener’s syndrome is a type of primary ciliary dyskinesia characterized by the classical triad of

  • Situs inversus
  • Chronic sinusitis
  • Bronchiectasis

Infertility in Kartagener’s syndrome is due to asthenospermia (immotile spermatozoa due to impaired sperm flagella function), not azoospermia (complete absence of spermatozoa in ejaculate).

Primary ciliary dyskinesia (also called immotile cilia syndrome) is an autosomal recessive disorder affecting ciliary motility. It occurs due to ultrastructural defects in the dynein arm of cilia. This causes the retention of secretions due to a failed mucociliary clearance mechanism. Clinically, this manifests as chronic sinusitis and recurrent infections that ultimately lead to bronchiectasis. As ciliary function is necessary to ensure proper rotation of the developing organs in the chest and abdomen, its absence will lead to situs inversus or a partial lateralizing abnormality. Approximately half of the patients with primary ciliary dyskinesia have Kartagener syndrome.

questions.text: Which is the most common cause of lung abscess?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of lung abscess is aspirated oropharyngeal secretion.

Lung abscess represents necrosis and cavitation of the lung following microbial infection. They are broadly divided into two categories:

  1. Primary lung abscesses: usually arise from aspiration, often caused principally by anaerobic bacteria (most common)
  2. Secondary lung abscesses: arise in the setting of an underlying condition, such as a post-obstructive process (e.g., a bronchial foreign body or tumor) or a systemic process (e.g., HIV infection or another immunocompromising condition)

questions.text: A bed-ridden patient with a Ryles tube tried to pull out the tube. This led to aspiration following which he developed fever with chills and cough. X-ray findings were suggestive of lung abscess. Which of the following pathogens is unlikely to have caused it?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a primary lung abscess. Staphylococcus is involved in the formation of secondary lung abscess, not primary.

Microbial pathogens causing lung abscess:

Clinical conditions

Pathogens

Primary lung abscess (due to aspiration)

Anaerobes (e.g., Peptostreptococcus spp., Prevotella spp., Bacteroides spp., Streptococcus milleri), microaerophilic streptococci

Secondary lung abscess (due to underlying conditions)

Staphylococcus aureus, gram-negative rods (e.g., Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Enterobacteriaceae), Nocardia spp., Aspergillus spp., Legionella spp., Pneumocystis jirovecii

Embolic lesions

Staphylococcus aureus (often from endocarditis), Fusobacterium necrophorum (Lemierre’s disease)

questions.text: A 64-year-old man was admitted to the emergency department after being found unconscious due to alcohol intoxication. On physical examination, his dental hygiene was poor. Chest auscultation revealed fixed amphoric breath sounds over the right hemithorax. Which of the following lung lobes is most likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a primary lung abscess due to aspiration. Most common lobes involved in primary lung abscess are posterior upper lobes and superior lower lobes, given the predisposition of aspirated materials to be deposited in these areas.

The right lung is affected more commonly than the left because the right mainstem bronchus is less angulated.

In secondary abscesses, the location of the abscess may vary with the underlying cause.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents with persistent fever and productive cough for 6 weeks with night sweats and anemia. The following is his CXR. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario described along with the chest X-ray image showing air-fluid level is suggestive of a lung abscess.

The patients usually present with complaints of fever, cough with sputum production, and chest pain. Patients with putrid lung abscesses may report foul-smelling sputum. Patients with chronic lung abscesses usually have a history of night sweats, fatigue, and anemia.

On physical examination:

  • Poor dentition/gingival disease
  • Amphoric and/or cavernous breath sounds on lung auscultation
  • Digital clubbing
  • The absence of a gag reflex

CXR features of lung abscess:

  • A lung cavity with an air-fluid level
  • The cavity wall is thick and irregular, and a surrounding pulmonary-infiltrate is often present
  • Computed tomography (CT) is more sensitive than chest radiography and is used to detect small cavities

The two x-ray images given below show thick-walled cavities with air-fluid levels on lateral and PA views respectively.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presented with 2 weeks of productive cough, fever, and shortness of breath. A chest radiogram was done as shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate therapy for him?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, the patient most likely has a lung abscess as depicted by the radiograph. Clindamycin is the drug of choice in the treatment of lung abscesses.

When there are contraindications to clindamycin, a combination of penicillin and metronidazole is likely to be as effective as clindamycin.

Anaerobes of oral origin are the most common causative organism and require broad-spectrum antibiotic coverage. Vancomycin, ciprofloxacin, and cephalexin have no significant activity against anaerobes.

Below is a chest X-ray showing a lung abscess (yellow dotted circle) with an air-fluid level (arrow).

questions.text: A patient with fever, productive cough, night sweats, and clubbing is diagnosed with lung abscess. Which of the following is an unlikely complication of this condition?
questions.solution:
Lung carcinoma is unlikely in patients with lung abscesses. Lung carcinoma may cause lung abscess (in 10-15% of cases) but lung abscess is not a premalignant condition.

Complications of lung abscess:

  • Empyema
  • Pneumatocele
  • Bronchopleural fistula
  • Bronchiectasis
  • Metastatic infections like brain abscess
  • Life-threatening hemoptysis
  • Massive aspiration of lung abscess contents

questions.text: What is the most common presentation of inhalational anthrax?
questions.solution:
The most common presentation of inhalation anthrax is hemorrhagic mediastinitis, which is seen in 38% of the patients.

Inhalational anthrax also known as wool sorter’s disease is caused by Bacillus anthracis. Infection usually occurs among workers handling contaminated animal wool, hair, and skin in textile and tanning industries.

Patients present with malaise, fever, cough, shortness of breath & headache. B. anthracis spores are phagocytosed by alveolar macrophages and transported to mediastinal lymph nodes. Hemorrhagic necrosis of the thoracic lymph nodes draining the lung results in hemorrhagic mediastinitis. Pulmonary infiltrates, mediastinal widening, and pleural effusion are other findings.

Treatment of inhalation anthrax includes a combination of intravenous ciprofloxacin and clindamycin for at least 14 days, antitoxins (Raxibacumab, Obiltoxaximab), anthrax immunoglobulins and steroids (if associated meningitis is present).

Prophylaxis with ciprofloxacin (500mg twice daily for 2 months) is recommended for anyone at high risk of inhalational exposure to anthrax spores.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a common feature of allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis?
questions.solution:
Central bronchiectasis is a typical feature of allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA), not distal bronchiectasis. 

ABPA is an eosinophilic pulmonary disorder caused by a hypersensitivity reaction to the colonization of airways by the fungus Aspergillus fumigatus. It occurs almost exclusively in patients with asthma (~2.5% of patients) or cystic fibrosis (up to 15%). In chronic cases, repeated episodes of bronchial obstruction, inflammation, and mucoid impaction can lead to bronchiectasis, fibrosis, and respiratory compromise. While central bronchiectasis is characteristic, some patients can develop chronic cavitary lesions.

With the development of ABPA, asthma or cystic fibrosis typically worsens and may manifest with a new or worsening cough or an increase in sputum production or wheezing. Many patients report coughing up thick sputum casts. The presence of hyperattenuating mucus in the airways is highly specific.

ABPA is diagnosed serologically, based on the presence of:
Serum IgE > 1000 IU/ml
Positive skin prick test or IgE levels against A. fumigatus extract
Detection of Aspergillus-specific antibodies
Eosinophilia >500 cells/μL

Treatment - The use of systemic glucocorticoids is indicated for ABPA, but the course should be tapered by 3-6 months. Antifungal agents like itraconazole, voriconazole, and newer azoles can be used for over 4 months to control disease activity. Monoclonal antibodies against IgE, IL-4, and IL-5 receptors can be used for severe refractory cases.

questions.text: Which of the following tests is not used to diagnose a patient with suspected allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis?

choices.text: Culture of Aspergillus fumigatus from sputum

questions.solution:
The culture of Aspergillus fumigatus from sputum is not a diagnostic criterion for allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA). The sensitivity of sputum culture in ABPA is low.

ABPA is diagnosed serologically, based on the presence of:

  • Serum IgE > 1000 IU/ml.
  • Positive skin prick test or IgE levels against A. fumigatus extract.
  • Detection of Aspergillus-specific antibodies.
  • Eosinophilia >500 cells/μL.

questions.text: A patient with acute myeloid leukemia underwent induction therapy. Within the next few days, he developed a cough and fever. On evaluation, HRCT showed a halo sign. Eventually, the patient deteriorated and died due to respiratory compromise. On autopsy, lung histopathology showed infarction and invasion of blood vessels by Aspergillus hyphae. Which of the following is not true about this condition?

choices.text: Fungal hyphae are broad and aseptate
Yeast forms are not seen in infected tissue
Most of the patients are asymptomatic
Exposure to hay barns is a risk factor.

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of aspergillosis. Fungal hyphae of Aspergillus species are narrow, septate, and have branching at 45o. 

Yeast forms of Aspergillus are not seen in infected tissue.

Exposure to the high number of conidia that are found in construction sites, hay barns, moldy barks, and composts is a risk factor.

Clinical features: 

  • Most of the patients are asymptomatic
  • Fever
  • Cough
  • Chest discomfort
  • Trivial hemoptysis
  • Shortness of breath

Halo sign-on HRCT refers to a localized ground glass appearance representing an area of hemorrhagic infarction surrounding a nodule. It is seen in invasive aspergillosis, a distinct entity where there is a direct invasion of hyphae into the lung tissue.

The air crescent sign describes the crescent of air that can be seen in invasive aspergillosis. It usually heralds recovery and is the result of increased granulocyte activity.

Monod sign refers to the gas that surrounds a mycetoma (most commonly an aspergilloma) in a pre-existing pulmonary cavity.
